OriginalSource.Creator: Terese Winslow
OriginalSource.Comment: Made cancer spot on omentum more visible; made the omentum tissue look more shear and less like gray stripes.
Added the omentum and moved the cancer spot and the tumor size inset box to the omentum, per reviewer.
Removed the cancer spot that is on the right fallopian tube near the top of the uterus

Removed the cancer spots that aren’t in the ovaries and fallopian tubes; removed the cancer that is growing out of the ovaries onto adjacent tissue; on the cancer spot that has the pull out box coming from it, extended the cancer a tiny bit so that it is actually in the peritoneum layer.

REVISED IMAGE per FIGO update: Removed "ovarian cancer" from title; labeled the Lymph nodes on the lower, left side of the image; removed the entire lymph node group labeled “b”; and removed the letter “a” from the lower right cancer spot
Moved the cancer spot (labeled “a”) and the “Tumor size” box to the lower right part of the illustration; put the cancer spot on the peritoneum next to the “Peritoneum” label pointer.

ContentDescriptions.ContentDescription: Drawing of stage IIIC shows cancer inside both ovaries that has spread to the omentum. The cancer in the omentum is larger than 2 centimeters. An inset shows 2 centimeters is about the size of a peanut. Also shown are the small intestine, colon, fallopian tubes, uterus, bladder, and lymph nodes behind the peritoneum.

Drawing of stage IIIC shows cancer inside both ovaries that has spread to the omentum. The cancer in the omentum is larger than 2 centimeters. An inset shows 2 centimeters is about the size of a peanut. Also shown are the small intestine, colon, fallopian tubes, uterus, bladder, and lymph nodes behind the peritoneum.

Captions.MediaCaption: In stage IIIC, cancer is found in one or both ovaries or fallopian tubes and has spread to the omentum, and the cancer in the omentum is larger than 2 centimeters. Cancer may have spread to lymph nodes behind the peritoneum or to the surface of the liver or spleen.

In stage IIIC, cancer is found in one or both ovaries or fallopian tubes and has spread to the omentum, and the cancer in the omentum is larger than 2 centimeters. Cancer may have spread to lymph nodes behind the peritoneum or to the surface of the liver or spleen.

MediaContent.Comment: 2016-01-26: Revised content & caption approved by OCC; added HP content & caption.
